title: Viktor Onopko
text:
Viktor Savelyevich Onopko (; born 14 October 1969) is a Russian <a href="association%20football">football</a> coach and a former <a href="defender%20%28football%29">defender</a> of Ukrainian origin. He is an assistant coach with the <a href="Russia%20national%20football%20team">Russia national football team</a>.
He held the record for most international appearances for the <a href="Russia%20national%20football%20team">Russian national team</a> until 8 September 2015, when he was overtaken by <a href="Sergei%20Ignashevich">Sergei Ignashevich</a>.
Club career.
Born in Voroshilovgrad (now <a href="Luhansk">Luhansk</a>), <a href="Soviet%20Union">Soviet Union</a>, Onopko's career as a player started in 1986 and finished in 2005; during this time he played for <a href="FC%20Shakhtar%20Donetsk">Shakhtar Donetsk</a>, <a href="FC%20Spartak%20Moscow">Spartak Moscow</a>, <a href="Real%20Oviedo">Real Oviedo</a>, <a href="Rayo%20Vallecano">Rayo Vallecano</a>, <a href="FC%20Alania%20Vladikavkaz">Alania Vladikavkaz</a> and <a href="FC%20Saturn%20Ramenskoe">FC Saturn</a>.
International career.
Although he was eligible to play for <a href="Ukraine%20national%20football%20team">Ukraine</a>, Onopko chose to play for Russia and amassed 109 caps (plus 4 for the <a href="CIS%20national%20football%20team">CIS</a>, including the ones in <a href="1992%20European%20Football%20Championship">Euro 92</a>), the first coming in 1992. He played in the <a href="Football%20World%20Cup%201994">1994</a> and <a href="Football%20World%20Cup%202002">2002</a> <a href="Football%20World%20Cup">World Cup</a>s, as well as <a href="1996%20European%20Football%20Championship">Euro 96</a>. Onopko was in the preliminary squad for <a href="2004%20European%20Football%20Championship">Euro 2004</a> but was dropped due to injury. With the national team, in 2003 he won the <a href="Cyprus%20International%20Football%20Tournament">Cyprus friendly tournament</a>
In 2009, he was part of the <a href="Russian%20national%20football%20team">Russia</a> squad that won the <a href="2009%20Legends%20Cup">2009 Legends Cup</a>.
Coaching career.
He worked for 11 years as an assistant coach for <a href="PFC%20CSKA%20Moscow">PFC CSKA Moscow</a>.
On 26 July 2021, he was hired as an assistant to <a href="Valeri%20Karpin">Valeri Karpin</a> in the <a href="Russia%20national%20football%20team">Russia national football team</a>.
Personal life.
Viktor has a younger brother, <a href="Serhiy%20Onopko">Serhiy</a>, who also played as a professional footballer.
